document.title: Ohio’s Learning Standards – Extended with Learning Progressions Social Studies

26C7C799E11C42B8ACE0C101BBEDF78C.description:
Understand that the Federal Reserve System works to
maintain economic stability. For instance, keeping prices
from rising or falling too fast or making sure banks have
enough money to pay their customers During the Great
Depression many banks did not have enough money on
hand.

38DABD580FF54AF5A14BCC2DFD6E6C7D.description:
Understand that the Federal Reserve System makes
decisions that impact the economy. For example, the
Federal Reserve System sets the minimum amount of
money banks must keep on hand. Raising or reducing the
reserve requirement influences how much money is in
circulation.

CFA9B1267A744737A586D73B5CD028A1.description:
Match the Federal
Reserve with its
purpose.

1D2768F622294AFA8853DF245845F24B.description:
Identify the three
main functions of the
Federal Reserve.

22898AF2AFDA4158BF27B36676907762.description:
Explain the
purpose of the
Federal Reserve
(e.g., who, what,
where, and how
it works; what it
does).

C748D6FA3FA54AEDA4CEA1535FE5D6D5.description:
The Federal
Reserve System uses
monetary tools to regulate
the nation’s money supply
and moderate the effects of
expansion and contraction in
the economy

F75E00D5F3B54174ADB5BA72EA19C35F.description: Engage as a producer or consumer.

C09AA95D98264256908F7F6C0C5C4DC5.description:
Understand economy as a system that organizes
exchange of money, goods and services, and
producers and consumers.

715F595EF94849899A8B231525D2985A.description:
Understand economic policy as the management of wealth
and resources of a country or region.

F0618EBBCFA24EA4A76C82565CC4C7F6.description:
Recognize the federal government’s role in maintaining
a stable economy.

AF3BA2AEC88D4AF2AC600D4CE09CBA74.description:
Understand economic policy as the management of wealth
and resources of a country or region.

E94D1CF5082C43A281321AC54DA9C0DA.description:
Understand that the federal government can increase
or decrease spending to influence the economy. For
instance, the government could spend more funds on
highways, resulting in more jobs available for
workers.

0968C7ACDA93415D8858776F37796B5B.description:
Understand that the federal government can raise or
lower taxes to impact the economy. For instance, raising
taxes will increase the cost of goods and services,
eventually making purchases more expensive for
consumers.

EE5E6954EEA64E49BE38A9AF2AE4F8FE.description:
Identify the fiscal tools the federal government can use
to influence the economy, including tax rates, spending,
and regulation.

F66D0DA23466450CB182BFA9A94700C7.description:
Identify federal
organizations or
agencies that
are supported
by federal tax
money.

61B4AF224ED04365B4F251BBE1F4C903.description:
Match
federal organizations
or agencies supported
by federal tax money
with the services of the
organization or
agency.

56C12F69711B42B3A51461992A2FF6AD.description:
Research and
explain what
the federal
government
uses tax
dollars for
(e.g.,
infrastructure,
education,
defense,
healthcare).

18A3394920294537A94415E4F4FACECE.description:
The federal
government uses spending
and tax policy to maintain
economic stability and foster
economic growth. Regulatory
actions carry economic costs
and benefits.

3F0579D67C4C41E5BE60522C2B3FF5C0.description: Engage with public officials and/or public policy issues.

3167009388FF47378002985707449283.description: Sort public policy issues as local, state, or federal.

B3814AB678D6475391DBF46B35BD9D68.description:
Identify civic participation as a role an individual can
play to shape public policy.

ABC749286660496BA1A02B271FF37F20.description:
Identify ways to engage in civic participation (e.g.,
voting, attending meetings, volunteering, communicating
with elected representatives, participating in political
demonstrations, volunteer with local agencies (e.g.,
libraries, police stations, fire stations, public health clinics).

6FDDBB3A7B134B678B86BAFE72616A97.description:
Understand that citizens who support a common
cause may join an organization to amplify their voice
and influence elected officials.

AA2D2873B9A84BA58E4EC8CEFAB12E15.description:
Recognize ways to inform policy decisions, including
campaigning for candidates, conducting a letter writing
campaign, participating in public demonstrations,
attending and offering comments at a public meeting,
providing testimony before a committee, or meeting
with elected officials.

FCA0DE5E722A4E40AA0B000F23ACB497.description:
Match public officials (e.g., mayor, assemblyman) or
government entities (e.g., school board, board of
health) with examples of public policy issues for which
they are responsible.

E79DBEB03D314165B975755794AA2B08.description:
Identify ways an
individual plays
a role in shaping
federal, state
and local policy
(e.g., voting).

FDE7148245C84B9090481E8906EE817B.description:
Identify ways
an individual or
organization
plays a role in
shaping
federal, state
and local
policy.

C98E9F432829452EA2A209D2C2347CFE.description:
Research and
explain ways
individuals and
organizations play
a role in shaping
federal, state or
local policy.

3DAC1F3E36874D91B988ED83305A4AEF.description:
Individuals
and organizations play a role
within federal, state, and
local governments in helping
to determine public
(domestic and foreign)
policy.

5531CACFDFD64AA389ABEFFACA4F07A5.description: Engage in respectful discussions around public policy.

FE0B66D12063402D89C497CD1240826E.description: Identify key community and state leaders.

C720FADB76524F77A0AD3A5408F9B0E4.description: Match community/local and state leaders with their entity.

FEBCC81C4A6B4169B65B5A5827B5E263.description:
Recognize the three branches of government:
legislative, executive, and judicial.

BE51E829E26D47EB87BD89E833E928D1.description:
Understand that multiple groups (entities) make
decisions within the three branches of government.
Entities could include committees, boards, and
departments.

0354E78A42134B4CAD3A015EEFE5162F.description:
Define public policy as matters of discussion and debate
related to needs of the community.

89232F955F0149F78611C99600921E89.description:
Match an entity
with its appropriate
branch of
government.

3D139A3549B24E5098BB63C522C2A0D2.description:
Identify an entity
within the three
branches of
government at the
federal, state and
local levels.

F9D6301211FF46CDB7DBA7A663B8849C.description:
Describe an
entity within the
three branches of
government at
the federal, state
and local levels.

8AC3498BF1D3468F847F704FEBFA6ADE.description:
A variety of
entities within the three
branches of government, at all
levels, address public policy
issues which arise in domestic
and international affairs.

DBA20D7CB6ED42228FFEB494D88B5B72.description:
Engage in a classroom job that requires personal
responsibility.

D217A10208D94B55B9CFA54745672723.description:
Define responsibilities as the expectation to use individual
rights in ways that respect the rights of others.

08B221DFB8AA40DA8C6CA3CB86375C01.description:
Identify problems that are directly affecting learners and
their families in the local community.

0728A262E6E4400C82F728866F1DC5AB.description:
Understand that rights come with responsibilities using
local and state examples (e.g., participating in
community meetings, sharing your point of view with
local leaders, volunteering at public events, voting).

E21595464F36465A8D6F8F3E04E0DC28.description:
Actively participate
in a group activity
to make a change
in the school.

4CE3F4555B5845D980C018203C95B0DE.description:
Contribute to planning
or participating in a
group activity to make
a change in the
school or community.

4164212476FB41A9987358338EDE3469.description:
Identify steps that
need to be taken
to make a positive
change in the
school or local
community.

B8655C0ECD8241388B5C8351529419FA.description:
Individuals in
Ohio have a responsibility
to assist state and local
governments as they
address relevant and often
controversial problems that
directly affect their
communities.

588C3AA23B854D078A9E3AF46B09561F.description:
Engage in learning experiences referencing the
Ohio Constitution

C4C167DCA6394C3381670AC662F52118.description:
Understand that constitutions establish the structure and
function of governments and the role of citizens in their
government.

A816568AAA1D449182D552787B6C1A53.description:
Create a timeline that includes the adoption of the
U.S. Constitution and the adoption of Ohio’s
Constitution.

4FE4D31CB4EC49F2BDA75CA2B56E9C02.description:
Understand that there are multiple levels of government
in a federal system (e.g., federal, state, local).

05704B07169E4937B0DD8D228FC6E8E9.description:
Identify the U.S. Constitution as the supreme law of
the land. State and local laws can exceed, but not
contradict federal law.

2BF96324D27649E6A830484B901D2BF1.description:
Recognize that the Ohio and U.S. Constitutions
established three branches of government:
legislative, executive, and judicial.

9E92E752DA0049549889FB8AA58FA24B.description:
Identify the differences between the Ohio and U.S.
Constitutions, such as election of judges, term limits for
legislators, and ability to make laws through public
action.

96E3C4EC93C9447CB2D9D23E6EF90C07.description:
Select ways the
Ohio Constitution
protects the needs
of the people.

21DBB6D06F554D1A83AD9D800EEB9337.description:
Explain how the Ohio
Constitution works
together with the
federal Constitution
to protect people in
Ohio.

796F20D4483342B69CD8C0FE3979A149.description:
Compare and
contrast the Ohio
Constitution with
the federal
Constitution to
identify
similarities that
protect the
people of Ohio.

5E242A5E99F744789EEC2CA9CB610DE0.description:
As a framework
for the state, the Ohio
Constitution has similarities
and differences to the federal
Constitution; it was changed
in 1851 to address difficulties
governing the state.

A2B563949DCB4CF981DA294974E830D1.description:
Engage in civic participation opportunities through
freedoms of expression, press, assembly, and
petition.

2070353F63E7411985AF9456538501CC.description:
Define marginalized groups as people who are
discriminated against and denied rights others
have.

10854D8CDBFF4909B5BBA730C8DF61F5.description:
Define civil rights as rights protected by the U.S.
Constitution. Civil rights include the right to vote and other
opportunities for civic participation.

26DD8525E458480EA218E6FDAC7AACAA.description:
Understand that civil rights have been extended
to marginalized groups over time.

337148AC77B84CC08C40A43277E41034.description:
Identify a
constitutional
amendment
that increases
opportunities for
civic
participation.

D54E579D6DB24C8FBB6231DAADC7273E.description:
Identify constitutional
amendments that
affect marginalized
groups in the United
States (e.g., 14th,
15th, 19th and 24th
Amendments).

99445F60E28946059EDAA11E526680D4.description:
Explain the
constitutional
amendments that
explicitly affect
marginalized
groups in the
United States (e.g.,
women’s suffrage,
civil rights, voting
rights).

D737ADB327D049F59D96C083B64B1D74.description:
Historically, the
United States has struggled
with majority rule and the
extension of minority rights.
As a result of this struggle,
the government has
increasingly extended civil
rights to marginalized groups
and broadened opportunities
for participation.

94FCC567B4BC42D6938D27FB75728D2A.description: Engage in actions that respect the rights of others.

FA80578527BE47FA90FB9288619545AC.description:
Identify rights and responsibilities students have within
the classroom, home, and community.

7C100A570E6A41938398FFFA6E16AF5C.description:
Define rights as personal freedoms protected by laws
that balance individual rights and the good of the
community (freedom within limits).

7C4F1173C0144FF3B31AFD1826580AFB.description:
Define responsibilities as the expectation to use individual
rights in ways that respect the rights of others.

112B050C5A354FA09F3AEAB0FBF34A3A.description:
Identify a right as
provided by the
U.S. Constitution.

2E42117E83AC49B2AC89AE5A49D01FCF.description:
Identify a right in the
U.S. Constitution that
affects high school
students (e.g., voting
age of 18, I turn 18
next month).

5EFA27C9680543E89128528102FFBBD0.description:
Given a right
from the U.S.
Constitution,
explain the
right and the
responsibilities

80BF09B501794EDE8F553C27ADEC3B5A.description:
In the United
States, people have rights
which protect them from
undue governmental
interference. Rights carry
responsibilities, which help
define how people use their
rights and which require
respect for the rights of
others.

B12A494B2A204F5EB33B4AF8CD5635AF.description: Engage with a news source around a current issue.

F5046D549B484461A1841531BA13F7C6.description: Choose a story from a news source about a law.

8A0632B7AECC4FCFBC189E33DC592528.description:
Recognize the three branches of government
as legislative, executive, and judicial.

AD7C4DCB5EFF41A4A9DAA406A9CAC4FD.description:
Identify the roles or actions of the branches of government
in a news story about a current issue.

25F1D66EE6274B2DAC59BCF990373ED2.description:
Identify
governments as
the source of
laws that protect
the people by
addressing
current issues.

6F0EAE7B9F384908A8A19BE9FFBDBFFD.description:
Explain a political
process that
creates a dynamic
interaction
between the three
branches of
government (e.g.,
checks and
balances).

62CA93B88CF34DD4A8EA30AA55CE4615.description:
Given an event,
explain how it
creates a dynamic
interaction among
the three branches
of government
(e.g., checks and
balances).

BCC921A99C024357B213F61DD1039439.description:
The political
process creates a dynamic
interaction among the three
branches of government in
addressing current issues.

3870D06300E84C3E99CCC1BB1C2313FE.description: Structure and Functions of the Federal Government

2AE1DEACA67949DFB584197F315BF0DB.description:
Engage with personnel linked to the three branches of
government.

301EF4EFC03D4BFC8705A42A1D7379D1.description:
Identify that governments help society run (e.g.,
trash collection, voting, military-national
security).

23D3735736E24701A0FBD53D4ABBD982.description: Identify the three branches of government.

FBEC770110EB4478A1CCC873ACDA0C9B.description:
Match each branch of government to the building where
it operates.

7082CDF511244B50B9A6D69221782210.description:
Identify the leaders of each of the three branches
(e.g., president - executive Branch).

127D65009D3E4783A67F2C6E7338B980.description:
Identify local, state, and federal personnel linked to each
of the three branches (e.g., local - police - executive
branch).

EA74EE3D4FA4431796D6D26EEEBCE413.description:
Match the
branches of
government
with one of
their respective
duties.

52581190CEB3404EBD0DF44D97FA5E76.description:
Explain how the
three branches of
the government
work together.

330D1EC5ABA14CE2BBEA6306167195A4.description:
Explain ways
the different
people/groups
in government
can limit each
other’s powers
(e.g., checks and
balances).

161FC406745B4551B56A5B0866DFE5EC.description:
Law and
public policy are created
and implemented by three
branches of government; each
functions with its own set of
powers and responsibilities.

080201492A5B45F9A69605E8F2D0A462.description: Structure and Functions of the Federal Government

E63BAD8DFDF24784B5AB8E2361EAACCE.description:
Engage in conversations about changes in rules
or routines.

215DA2DE25FB40D3B726F0FC57DE8889.description: Engage in learning around constitutional amendments.

C45DACFA2ADB4D88844DEF5C7AEED116.description: Define an amendment as a minor change in a document.

56E4AF2CC07A401B8A12AEE7E0C41A54.description:
Identify that federal governmental documents containing
laws cannot be changed unless the amendment process
is completed.

698E125CDA7548288C711B8FF77D7A49.description:
Participate in discussions about why changes to rules
and laws may be necessary.

2D3B513889414823B38FC6CA24A841E7.description:
Outline the two possible processes to make amendments
to the U.S. Constitution.

F8FEFF16948C4886A939A9ACA9C46AF3.description:
Identify historical amendments to structures and
functions of federal government (12th Amendment -
separate ballot for president and vice president, 23rd -
DC. electoral votes, 22nd - presidential term limit, 25th -
presidential successions).

7BA1C643FC0A4A9C8EC3A808F61277D8.description:
Match historic events to specific amendments (a health
concern/assassination of the president led to the
amendment, including presidential successions or FDR
was elected four times and led to the amendment,
including presidential term limits).

0B3A2F7B8B1B4453BE0252F9769E9801.description:
Understand that amendments are used to make
changes to or clarify how government functions.

AD1BD8E87FC9423EB69331FBF582D8F1.description: Amendments are used to change the U.S. Constitution.

254BF25EF5E04E1293A1F2F62C12F07F.description:
Identify an
amendment to the
Constitution.

56731ABB494A40C1B0C8AFF0577CE781.description:
Identify a
constitutional
amendment that has
altered the structure
and function of the
government.

0D96ACE8EA824A6388274C68F9515FDF.description:
Explain how
constitutional
amendments
have altered
the structure
and function
of the federal
government.

1BC73B6D280E424C90F4649C3559E040.description:
Constitutional
amendments have altered
provisions for the structure
and functions of the federal
government.

238896759D7E429ABB2C79016429DA20.description: Engage in learning around constitutional amendments.

C8C1D614F0154FCBB75BB2D08CC61BB5.description:
Identify people whose rights were limited e.g., women,
African-Americans, impoverished, and 18-20 year olds
(15th, 19th, 24
th
, and 26th Amendments).

276E1EC84D40464092292F3CFBFAD183.description:
Identify constitutional rights that have been extended
to groups of people who have been disenfranchised.

C62523ED9A38467CBE00C312AA065B75.description:
Select a right
added to the U.S.
Constitution in
order to provide for
disenfranchised
groups.

9BF00EA693DC40D6A73517DB2FF24E09.description:
Identify the
constitutional
amendments that
have provided rights
for disenfranchised
groups.

CF532660A4314FA4BDEA101854973FEE.description:
Describe the
constitutional
amendments that
have provided
civil rights for
disenfranchised
groups in the
U.S.

46520C2AE3B048B0A37851CD9A8664A4.description:
Constitutional
amendments have provided
for civil rights, such as
suffrage, for disenfranchised
groups.

5F9788D0BD294FA0A8D973C5D22C0E27.description:
Actively engage or actively participate as a
demonstration of equality.

D8E565B3F8704B0E9500201314E0D9F6.description: Discuss a time when individuals felt/were left out.

01814882A57C4224A7F254155C291522.description: Identify marginalized groups of people in today’s society.

6AC4524131BA4C3191C0D765E25BAE08.description:
Identify a marginalized group of people during the time
of Reconstruction

A6537C25D4D949E581213F418516D3A4.description:
Amendments are added to the Constitution in response to
societal/political changes.

546E7F2CCC064F03A85035A5BE9D3C74.description:
Identify the focus of the Reconstruction Amendments
as African-American rights.

1F28210FBBDF4CCDB642ED45CC0D2034.description:
Associate specific amendments with the
extension of rights to all African-Americans
(Reconstruction
Amendments: 13th Amendment - prohibited slavery, 14th
Amendment - citizenship and protection for all persons,
15th Amendment - voting rights).

CBB2453BF86F4D6DA24AC3CA8BD47EFA.description:
Select a right
added to the U.S.
Constitution during
the Reconstruction
period.

CB7C0FF82CF64F46BAEBA6D77CE41CAF.description:
Identify the United
States constitutional
amendments added
during the
Reconstruction
period.

B1B6B3F2565641A59682E795B64BF875.description:
Describe the
constitutional
amendments
added during the
Reconstruction
period.

4E7889E0B5DD484CB1805684006F254C.description:
The constitutional
amendments, known
collectively as the
Reconstruction Amendments,
extended new constitutional
protections to African
Americans, though the struggle
to fully achieve equality would
continue.

9D05279D3A6F4BEEBE842E6F45732C0A.description:
Engage in freedom of speech by expressing oneself
using any modality.

FA8997EC1C3141F3BCC7E4FCF338DDDC.description:
Engage with a replica of the U.S. Constitution, focusing on
the Bill of Rights.

9BA40F9BD0FC4950857217E9380A1002.description:
Understand that the Bill of Rights consists of 10
amendments to the U.S. Constitution.

4AFAAF1DC165451FA2FAAA487B5B16BC.description:
Identify that the First Amendment lists civil
liberties protected by the US Constitution.

9E143DBED0E749AF8C2F0EEAEEDF2486.description:
Match an
amendment to
the civil liberty
it protects (e.g.,
1st amendment
to Freedom of
Speech, Religion,
Press, Petition and
Assembly).

6B4C1D84F6D44616A8BB5C2BFEB52644.description:
Identify
a civil liberty listed in
the Bill of Rights and
its definition.

FE46496DEAFB452687EFE5C3691A07AB.description:
Summarize a civil
liberty protected in
the Bill of Rights.

27F04003D4474D1AB31D15430CC87DD5.description:
The Bill of Rights
was drafted to ensure the
protection of civil liberties of
the people and place limits on
the federal government.

DA1861B3BE6E47368CD254521A414022.description:
Engage in conversations about changes in rules
or expected behavior.

72A5B778DFFC4C73A14A0701B498723D.description: Propose a change to the classroom rules.

1DB4526058854FFC9380CAF9DB75FD7A.description: Define amendment as a change to a document.

5B7A976EEEE34A75B8F27D6B5A4BCB0C.description: Amendments are used to change the U.S. Constitution.

211DADE4B401422589858901B31D1435.description:
Identify legislation as a method to change how the
government acts on the ideas of the Constitution.

FF092132A8B54367913497225CC5DAC0.description:
Identify Supreme Court decisions as a method to change
how our government works or acts.

BB50743248C441F3A216CB5A74413229.description:
Identify a method
of change to the
U.S. Constitution.

0422180736D44D168619633BE864BDBD.description:
Identify
a specific change to
the U.S. Constitution
resulting from informal
practices.

404CC992CA0945FA98ECF8D908438E26.description:
Explain how and
why the U.S.
Constitution has
been or can be
changed.

72012E64420A4BAF9685E291F52D8244.description:
Constitutional
government in the United
States has changed over time
as a result of amendments to
the U.S. Constitution,
Supreme Court decisions,
legislation, and informal
practices.

37D03AE62CE64970927AFDB46F35E0CB.description: Engage to share an opinion about a rule or law.

22F026AD6C634D189D34C0DBE3F85B21.description:
Recall a time when you agreed/disagreed with a rule
or law.

6C68BF8374C7401795D70439DD543C20.description:
Identify an appropriate way to express
agreement/ disagreement with a rule or law.

36F4FACC4B464595B69CD0AF3A79B110.description:
Define debate as a public discussion that offers
views from opposing sides on a given topic.

776C96C943584E57B5A28C3EE9F01AED.description:
Identify public speaking and writing as a way to
participate in a debate.

B7D0667329B64AD1B32330708AC86D8A.description:
Define a primary source as a first-hand account of
an event.

CB2DDCCED6EB4CBB8A384DECDB331FCD.description:
Identify primary sources as Federalist (strong central
government) and Anti-Federalist (power to the states
and individual freedoms) Papers.

2AB0198FAD024C3BB4E9E5905F667BB4.description:
Match the ideas of strong central government vs.
states’ and individual rights to the correct set of papers.

7FFC0A8D9A994938BB2E0B7365476DA8.description:
Understand that the papers included letters, news
columns, and pamphlets written by multiple authors
expressing their views about federal government.

93DD78C8598842B5BA72B1D7A1B1D987.description:
Identify a
primary source
that discusses
the basic
principles of the
U.S. government
that led to the
adoption of the
Bill of Rights.

A9347E360C4048B4A085CF65003696DB.description:
Research and explain
(who, what, where,
when, how/why) a
primary source that
discusses the basic
principles of the U.S.
government that led
to the adoption of the
Bill of Rights.

ADB52E45AD2148778C0F6E10875AA4B4.description:
Research and
explain (who,
what, where,
when, how/why)
a primary source
that discusses
the basic
principles of the
U.S.
government that
led to the
adoption of the
Bill of Rights.

B0C9DE19BF884176B8A2CAD35E75CE4E.description:
The Federalist
Papers and the Anti-Federalist
Papers framed the national
debate over the basic
principles of government
encompassed by the
Constitution of the United
States and led to the adoption
of the Bill of Rights.

A622D2574844475EB482A187703D90CA.description: Engage with replica of the U.S. Constitution.

3F8DC7D6C44F47DA99815EC0AC5B53AD.description:
Engage with historic paintings or other representations
of the Constitutional Convention.

2318A2E31CCB48CF89DF2F45618DF848.description:
Engage with a timeline that includes documents in
American history.

E23B7063D1CB463C821B60574695FAB5.description:
Identify the 1787 signing of the Constitution on a timeline
of American history.

64E4433396094A19BA0448E928CE7723.description:
Understand that the Constitution outlines the laws or
rules of the United States.

DE9473F3C3D74C65B87425019A97BDCC.description:
Identify the U.S.
Constitution is
related to the
creation of the
government in the
United States.

20FF9155F7A04187B9061B5A415995E8.description:
Identify
key principles of the
U.S. Constitution that
provide the structure
to the government of
the United States.

8C9BC7D9CBFC466DBDAFEC6EA4F4DC77.description:
Explain basic
principles of
government in
the United States
(e.g., separation
of powers,
checks and
balances,
federalism).

8F2ABA1A7DD34B758486E82C5B97C254.description:
As the supreme
law of the land, the U.S.
Constitution incorporates
basic principles which help
define the government
of the United States as a
federal republic, including
its structure, powers, and
relationship with the
governed.

F7207E8088DC4CD1914BD8FABEAD92A1.description: Basic Principles of the U.S. Constitution

31627BA2A8C041109E7CC46C533A8F6E.description: Engage in a process to come to a group decision.

02AFDC26274B466D8670CB099AEAAB44.description: Determine own opinion on a given topic.

CAA2C9CAED8D423183F0BA4C432FC173.description:
Contribute to a group decision by respectfully sharing
own opinion.

91FC2DDA0C464EAF97FBD4E6DC62AE40.description:
Participate in a vote to reach a group decision. Then,
participate in a group discussion to reach a consensus
decision. Identify the differences.

64458377EDA2436799CAD44AF624088D.description:
Understand that a consensus decision is not a
majority vote, but a group decision all participants can
accept.

4E75A834335841128F0DDDE20527DFD4.description:
Understand that compromise is a decision-making process
where both parties give something up and experience a
benefit from the final decision.

EFF8C86F2AAA4DF895678A7B95899FED.description:
Understand that persuasion and negotiation are used to
influence others to change their opinion.

F0EA059FA9CD45DEA5FD88267C0C372F.description:
Match one of
the following
processes
(persuasion,
compromise,
consensus
building, or
negotiation)
to its
appropriate
situation.

D421CFF4933D4A4FA1CEC8E54582861E.description:
Choose one of the
following processes
(persuasion,
compromise,
consensus
building, or
negotiation) and
provide an example
of how it can
contribute to the
Democratic
process.

F4BD3B85F3AD4BE5AAF9D32E46DA8919.description:
Explain the
processes of
persuasion,
compromise,
consensus
building, or
negotiation and
how they
contribute to the
Democratic
process.

3038A7D8C1C44F87982808604BD5F6EE.description:
The processes
of persuasion, compromise,
consensus building, and
negotiation contribute to the
Democratic process.

C71B86E4DA9E4AA5AD75B78BF7FF2D53.description: Engage in the use of information from a variety of sources.

DC5D40CA8ECE44EEAFE4D94EAFE1E7E7.description:
Understand that sources of information are not
always credible.

62DA050B21DB4C64867A28432A661DC0.description:
Recognize that credible sources convey
accurate information supported by evidence.

D8808D2795C945F2956A714E41C6F0C9.description:
Identify features of credible sources (qualifications of the
writer/author, purpose of the content, agreement with other
credible sources, use of supporting evidence, disclosure of
biases due to affiliation(s).

64EA2F69F1FE4369BC96D13CE5B7F245.description:
Recognize a
credible source of
information that
describes a current
issue or issues.

F5B8E97613A04A74A8E7AEC4B5CD33D4.description:
Use two
related credible
sources of information
to describe a current
issue.

CB63D87176324177B8CA2B9FAB51DD27.description:
Select and/or use
relevant and
credible
informational
sources to
investigate a
current issue.

C7E5721F58EE42E6A3A56A0BB0320F52.description:
Issues can be
analyzed through the critical
use of credible sources.

6417D7CECFA4433B9218FB58567EC35C.description: Engage with people who have similar ideas/interests.

DC52031A3B41486182179D59BC3E6509.description:
Create a symbol to represent their classroom or
other group.

EFA1907B157B4AF686D16133BA32B5F8.description:
Match a political
party, interest
group, or media
outlet with its
symbol (e.g.,
the Republican
elephant, the
Democratic
donkey).

CD50D95F780A4E3F83E45DED8D045C87.description:
Identify
the various means
through which a
political party, interest
group, or media outlet
provides opportunities
for civic involvement.

96B1643AD2814B25B99E0CADD5544E8A.description:
Research political
parties, interest
groups, and media
outlets that provide
opportunities for
civic involvement
through various
means.

AD7DE8DD00C7417B877472E2677EE5C5.description:
Political parties,
interest groups, and the
media provide opportunities
for civic involvement through
various means.

2C15C1331A0F4049A02218E224792570.description: Actively participate/engage in a group activity.

481D013637AA4A3DAC30470B3AF59901.description:
Engage in a group decision making process in the
classroom.

8B9CDB1AE46D49FDA51E47CB44FC07AB.description: Identify a desired change in the school community.

7822FDF411B9490289CED9A58A7C1BD0.description:
Brainstorm ways students could work together to make
changes in the school

A2507FA80953475B98CDB76F2CD7E02A.description:
Understand that there is a planning process to organize
civic action toward change (determine the problem,
determine causes, explore solutions, gather input,
present their idea(s), make group decision, engage in
the selected action).

CCB26008BEA44C83B0E7524005778C0C.description:
Actively participate
in a group activity
to make a change
in the school.

6A18C6DF260E4C9BB1C1FA32E6C0A409.description:
Contribute to planning
or participating in a
group activity to make
a change in the
school or community.

378C5D95E77D408288FA34BF4BA2B06C.description:
Identify steps that
need to be taken
in order to make a
positive change in
the school or local
community.

A9C3BCE20F964E148AC53A42A98D163C.description:
Opportunities
for civic engagement within
the structures of government
are made possible through
political and public policy
processes.
